characters: SAM HOLDING HIS FORK ACROSS THE TABLE TO GIVE VICTORIA
SHOT OF HOUSEBOAT BEING TOWED BY A TUG DOWN THE RIVER
"AN AFFAIR TO REMEMBER" ON THE TELEVISION SET. DEBORAH
THE LIGHTS HAVE JUST GONE ON ON THE EMPIRE STATE BUILDING
A CHRISTMAS TREE GLITTERING WITH LIGHTS
ON ANNIE IN HER RENTAL CAR
SAM AND VICTORIA SHARING A LAUGH.
SAM ON THE BACK OF THE BOAT

dialogues.speaker: SAM BALDWIN
dialogues.text: A card: Chicago. He's in his thirties.  His neck is pinched into a crisp  dress shirt and tie.  His expression is vacant, faraway. A breeze blows but he doesn't react to it.  In the  distance the architecture of the Chicago skyline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy got sick and it happened  just like that and there was  nothing anybody would do. (continued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And pull back to reveal:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next to Sam is his son Jonah, age 9.  Sam's hand is on  his shoulder.  As the mourners go past and each takes a  turn shoveling a clod of dirt into an open grave --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we start asking why we'll go  crazy.  So, rule number one.   We don't ask why.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE REED
dialogues.text: Pretty, blonde, animated.  Jeans, a T-shirt, a Baltimore  Orioles hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? I just want to know why?  That's my first rule.  I always  ask why.  Come on.  Tell me.   C'mon, c'mon, c'mon --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And pull back to reveal:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie is talking to her boyfriend, a good-looking guy  named SETH.  They're carrying packing boxes into the  house they share in the Old Town section of Chicago.   The same stunning architecture in the b.g.  They go up  the back wooden staircase to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no why, Annie.  I'm  just not up for it.  I never  said I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there somebody else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't love me, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow them into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they set down the packing boxes and Seth starts to  assemble them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about ... you're too  narcissistic to commit to  another human being in a long- term way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agreeably) That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An attractive, thirtyish couple, SUZY and GREG are  stocking Sam's freezer with enough Ziploc meals for a  months.  A number of friends and relatives talk quietly  in the living room beyond.  Sam stands alone by a window  that looks into the backyard.  We can see a garden of  flowers -- clearly planted by Sam's wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes in the microwave.   Any one of them, five minutes  and done.  Ready to eat.  Do  you know how to make juice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Microwave.  Five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE'S KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Packing boxes.  Seth is moving out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take the microwave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I going to do with a  microwave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You turn it on, you open it and  you stand in front of it for a  very long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're angry.  Big deal.

dialogues.speaker: SAM'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: A large modern architectural firm in a Chicago high- rise.  Lake Michigan out the window.  A large space with  several architects consulting, drafting, etc.  Sam is at  his desk, working.  An older colleague, ROB, comes over  to him.  Rob has a mustache, smokes a pipe; he's kind  but a little stuffy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young man, it's none of my  business, but maybe you should  talk to someone.  I myself  have consulted a professional.   I used to be up tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Sam's face.  It's hard to imagine Rob being any more  uptight than he is.  Sam takes some business cards out  of his shirt pocket and reads them off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hypnotherapy...Shiatu Massage... Loss of Spouse support groups... Single parent discussion nights... Parents without partners. (starts riffling, angry) Partners without parents.   People who need people.  Guys  who go into the woods, beat  drums and bond.  Get a shrink.   Hug a friend.  Hug yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops, realizing that everyone in the room is staring  at him.  Quickly they pretend they weren't paying  attention.  Someone whispers something to a client.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continued) Don't mind him.  He's the guy  who just lost his wife. (beat) What I really think is we need  a change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea.  Take a few weeks  off, get some sun, take Jonah  fishing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head no) A real change.  New city.   Someplace where every time I go  around a corner I don't think  of Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And hold on Sam for a moment and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, Jonah and Maggie walking toward the field.  It's a  gorgeous day for a game.  They high-five each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you going to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And cut back to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sam snaps out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking about Seattle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Living Section of the paper.  Annie is blowing her  nose as she finishes telling her tale of woe to her  boss, LAURIE JOHNSON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, he wasn't right for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blowing her nose) I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't even wrong for you,  like cosmically wrong, so don't  beat up on yourself for  wasting...however long it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. (blowing her nose  again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pours Annie a cup of hot water.  Annie pulls a  teabag out of her pocket, puts it into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should see a shrink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home for the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) That's what I'm going to do.   I'm going to go home. (she thinks about it) I quit.  Laurie, I quit.  I'm  going back to Baltimore. (she's giddy) How does a blonde do a high- five?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smacks herself in the head.

dialogues.speaker: O'HARE AIRPORT
dialogues.text: The X where walkway K crosses with walkway L.  Coming  down walkway K are Sam, Jonah, Suzy, Greg, their son  MACK, and several other friends. And coming down walkway L is Annie with Laurie and a  couple of FRIENDS from the paper, JUDITH and DIANE. They pass each other going in diagonal directions and  continue on. We stay with Sam's group:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mack) Dad says I'm going to get used  to it, but I don't think you  can ever get used to a  designated hitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: overlap:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sam) Eventually, in a few months,  you'll start seeing women,  you'll meet someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move on.  Right.  That's what  I'm going to do.  In a few  months, boom, I'll be fine,  I'll just grow a new heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, she didn't mean --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is shaking his head no as they reach the gate for  the Seattle plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know. (emphatic) Look, it doesn't happen twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie's group, as they approach the gate for the  Baltimore plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to meet someone,  someone nice and stable who  wears a hat so he won't catch a  cold, and I'm going to marry  him and have three children  and live happily ever after.   I mean, I am not cut out for this  --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For life as we know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just make sure he isn't fat  like my Michael or you'll spend  your whole life worrying he's  going to drop dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, you guys are so romantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how long romance  lasts? (she snaps her fingers) That long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven still brings me flowers  every Friday and we've been  married 10 years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Diane) Honey, nobody wants to hear  that. (to Annie) Here, darling, have some Tic  Tacs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kissing everyone.  Annie starts toward the plane, loaded  with stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next time you see me I am  going to be incredibly happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Jonah sitting together as the plane waits on the  runway.  He notices his father's distractedness, reaches  over and takes his hand.  Sam comes back into focus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your dad.  Don't ever  forget that.  That's rule  number two. (beat) It's you and me, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie sitting by herself as the plane waits on the  runway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself) I guess it's just us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gulps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two planes face in opposite directions, waiting for  instructions. And now they both start to take off.  In opposite  directions. And we pull back back back back as the planes take off,  one flying east, the other flying west. And further and further back as they soar into the air  and leave the frame. The night sky. Stars twinkle. And now tilt down to see the United States.  It looks  like a cross between a satellite photo and a drawing by  Saul Steinberg. A light goes on in Baltimore. A light goes on in Seattle. They are the only lights on the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Annie comes out of the newspaper building with WALTER  JACKSON, a tall, handsome man who wears a hat.  They're  carrying an armful of Christmas presents.  They're  walking toward the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The short one with black hair  is your cousin Irene --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- who's married to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold, who ran away with his  secretary but came back --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- because Irene threatened to  put the dog to sleep if he  didn't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your brother Tom is a  psychology professor and is  married to...Betsy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- who is the most competitive  woman in the world --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They put the presents in the backs of their two cars and  pull out together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christmas lights twinkling as the two cars pull up in  front of a comfortable upper middle-class house and park  their cars.  They get out assembling presents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Uncle Milton lost all his  money in a Puerto Rican  condominium that went belly up,  don't mention the IRS or the  Federal prison system.  Your  mother is Barbara, your father  is Cliff --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope he doesn't get out his  slides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I what they had in mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going to love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they start toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody! Annie has an announcement --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and I are engaged!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the family's at the diner table.  Annie's family is  a completely normally-looking WASP family -- only  everyone is a little eccentric.  Annie's mother BARBARA,  a beautiful gray-haired, fantastically cheerful woman,  claps her hands together.  Her father CLIFF, who's at  the head of the table next to her, gives Annie a kiss.   Annie's brother TOM and his wife BETSY are at the table,  along with cousin IRENE and her husband HAROLD.  UNCLE  MILTON, who's Irene's father and Barbara's brother.   There are about FIVE CHILDREN there, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's wonderful, Annie.  I  hope it lasts... for years  and years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the competitive one) Do you have a ring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  Well.  How will anyone  know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're going to call  them all and tell them.   Congratulations, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He claps Walter on the back. Walter sneezes.  And sneezes again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing.  Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's probably just the flowers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll move them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch them.  I feel  terrible sneezing at a time  like this.  This is a big  moment for me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping) He's allergic to everything,  don't worry about it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bees.  I'm allergic to bees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not salmon I hope --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he eats one tiny piece of a  nut --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) My head swells up like a  watermelon and I drop dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the same with Harold and  bees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother and I had salmon at  our wedding, and I really think  a wedding without cold salmon --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not allergic to salmon.  I  don't think.  But you never  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, honey, I feel terrible, we  used up this magnum of  champagne we were saving on  something else, what did we use  it for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Milton's parole --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it was delicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was, wasn't it, Milton  darling --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are you getting married,  Annie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In early June.  In the garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it have to be in the garden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Harold and bees?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll spray you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cold salmon.  A lovely cucumber  salad.  Strawberries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I'm allergic to  strawberries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No strawberries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie smiles at Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Walter) Is that all right with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lou Gehrig line) Today I consider myself the  luckiest man on the face of  the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you wearing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you would wear my dress.   I only wore it once, and you'll  barely have to do anything to  it except take it in in the  bust --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have something that might do  --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is sitting on the couch as Cliff shows him slides  of cloud formations in Guatemala.  In the next room  Tom's at the piano and the kids are singing Christmas  carols.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAX, one of the children, is teaching Uncle Milton to  burp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of Christmas carols from below. The attic is full of boxes and Annie walks through with  her mother.  They come to a dressmakers dummy with a  sheet over it.  Barbara removes the sheet.  A beautiful  antique dress.  A veil sitting on top of the dummy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Historical Society wanted  this and I never would give it  to them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granny's dress.  Oh, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I notice these things are back  in fashion.  Oh, honey. (tears are rolling down  her face as she tries  the veil on Annie) He's a lovely man, Annie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  He's wonderful, isn't  he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are his folks nice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll love them.  We're going  down to D.C.  tonight to be with  them Christmas morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did it happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara starts to unbutton the tiny buttons on the back  of the dress and remove it from the dummy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's silly, really.  I mean,  I'd seen him at the office,  obviously I'd seen him, he's  the associate publisher, and  then one day we both ordered  sandwiches from the same place,  and he got my lettuce and  tomato sandwich on whole wheat,  which of course he was allergic  to, and I got his lettuce and  tomato on white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (utterly without irony) How amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is, isn't it? You make  millions of decisions that mean  nothing and then one day you  decide to order takeout and it  changes your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Destiny takes a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please.  Destiny's just  something we've invented  because we can't stand the fact  that everything that happens is  accidental.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how do you explain that  you both ordered exactly the  same sandwich except for the  bread? How many people in this  world like lettuce and tomato  without something else like  tuna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't a sign.  It was a  coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara shrugs, slips the dress off the dummy and Annie  steps into it. Barbra starts to button the dress on Annie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in Atlantic City with my  family.  Cliff was a waiter.   He talked me into sneaking out  for a midnight walk on the  Steel Pier.  I've probably told  you this a million times, but  I don't care.  And then he held  my hand.  I was scared.  All  sorts of thing were going  through my head.  But after a  while I forgot about them.  At  one point I looked down, at our  hands, and I couldn't tell  which fingers were mine and  which were his.  And I knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hearing it for the  first time) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she doesn't know, but  she doesn't want her  mother to know she  doesn't know) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magic.  It was magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeating) Magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew we would be together  forever, and that everything  would be wonderful, just the  way you feel about Walter.   Walter.  It's quite a formal  name, isn't it? (lowering her voice) One of the things I truly knew  was that your father and I were  going to have a wonderful time ... in the sack I believe you  call it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it took several years  before everything worked like  clockwork in that department,  so don't be worried if it takes  a while --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, we already...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, fine, fine.  Fiddle da  dee.  And how's it working?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like... clockwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to look in the mirror.  The dress doesn't fit  at all.  It's completely lopsided.  One shoulder is  higher than the other.  The waist is in the wrong spot.   The effect is quite comical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you'll get married in a new  dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) You don't believe in signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house Christmas lights sparkle outside, twinkling on  the tree inside, and the warm light spilling out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They loved you.  I told you  they would love you and they  did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Walter. (beat) Did anyone ever call you  anything other than Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even when you were young?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.  Not even when I was  young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's starting to rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you don't want to  drive with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How will I get back to  Baltimore Saturday? (remembering something) Oh God, I forgot my present for  your stepmother -- I took it  inside by accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly.  I'll just be  ten minutes behind you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Annie drives back toward Washington, D.C. Raining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie driving.  Presents on the front seat.  She's  singing "Sleigh Ride" and doing all the sound effects  and clipclops and giddyups.  After a moment, she  realizes she doesn't know all the words and turns on the  radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome back to "You and Your  Emotions." I'm Dr.  Marcia  Fieldstone broadcasting across  America from the top of the  Sears Tower in Chicago where we  would have a fantastic view of  Santa Claus and his reindeer if  there was a -- oops, never  mind.  Tonight we're talking  about wishes and dreams.   What's your wishes this Christmas  Eve? Maybe the best present  you can give yourself is a call  to me.  The number is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie changes the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The subject of the evening's  medical update is You and Your  Spleen and our host --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She flips the dial back the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our caller is from Seattle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie changes the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming up, Jingle Bells  backwards, sung by the New  Jersey Cape Mayettes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie twists the dial back the other way.  We hear a  YOUNG BOY's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, this is Jonah -- (there's a bleep as  Jonah says his last  name)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie's hand lingers on the dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No last names, Jonah.  Hello  there, you sound younger than  our usual callers.  How come  you're up so late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that late in Seattle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got me there.  What's your  Christmas wish, Jonah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not for me.  It's for my  dad.  I think he needs a new  wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like the one he was  now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't have one now.   That's the problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie closes her eyes for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the car drives along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to hear that, Jonah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been pretty sad, but I  think my dad is worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're worried about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm worried about him, he's  worried about me, I ride my  bike to school, he follows in  the car, like I'm not supposed  to know he's there.  Now it's  Christmas, and you know what  happens to people at Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lose their minds and call  crackpot doctors on the radio --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you talked to your dad  about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very hard for him to talk  about this stuff.  It's like it  makes him sadder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect.  Sandbag the father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you crazy? He thinks shows  like this are dumb.  If you  didn't have an 800 number I  could never get away with this  --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he home right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think I can help a  little more if I talk to him  directly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure he won't be angry once  he realizes how concerned you  are about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, but if I get yelled at,  I'm never gonna listen to this  show again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah is on the telephone on the first floor of the  houseboat he lives in with Sam.  He's got the phone cord  coming out of the small first-floor study, and he's  standing near the kitchen end of a large living area  looking out at the back deck, where his dad is sitting  in a deck chair looking out at the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's somebody on the phone  for you. (into phone) His name is Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is completely disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam pokes his head in the back door.  He looks much as  he did eighteen months earlier, except that his hair is  a little longer.  He picks up the phone extension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Sam, this is Dr. Marcia  Fieldstone on Network America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam looks across the room to Jonah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm probably not interested in  whatever you're selling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not selling anything.  Your  son called and asked for advice  on how to find you a new wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he really didn't get  her name) Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeating herself) Dr. Marcia Fieldstone of  Network America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, are we on the air?  Jonah, for God's sake --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be mad at me, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam can see Jonah.  He's frightened.  Sam immediately  feels how upset Jonah is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He feels that since your wife's  death you've been very unhappy.  He's genuinely worried about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is looking at Jonah, who's rooted to the spot he's  standing on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jonah) I'm not mad at you.  Okay, I'm  not mad at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's hard for him to  talk to you about all this.   Maybe we could talk and it  would make him feel a little  better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a grotesque violation  of this man's personal life,  but never mind --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All righ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  How long ago did your  wife die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been about a year and a  half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you had any relationship  since?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is very uncomfortable about this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Doctor, I don't want to  be rude, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't want to invade your  privacy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping) Sure you do --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, we had a tough time at  first, but I think I'm holding  my own as a dad, and Jonah and  I will get along fine again as  soon as I break his radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie laughs.  So does Mr.  Fieldstone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah is smiling too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no doubt that you're a  good dad.  You can tell a lot  from a person's voice.  But  something must be missing if  Jonah feels that you're still  under a cloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her how you don't sleep at  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Jonah both talk into their extensions, literally  talking to each other on the phone within their own  house, but also ON THE AIR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can hear you walking around  sometimes.  At first I thought  it was a robber.  Go ahead,  tell her, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I have to now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam starts across the room towards Jonah, who starts  toward him, both of them holding their phone receivers.   On the wall in the dining area is a pine bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's almost Christmas -- (as the two of them sit  down together on the  bench) A kid needs a mother --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts an arm around Jonah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Annie listens.  She's softened considerably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could it be that you need  someone just as much as Jonah  does?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie catches herself, covers her mouth in embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm losing my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Annie makes a turn off the beltway into a rest stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been talking to -- well,  let's just call him Sleepless  in Seattle, and we'll be right  back after this break with  listener response, your  response, to the things we've  been discussing.  The number to  call is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where other people get  to call in and dump on what you  said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the beginning of a commercial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie walks in, anxious to break the spell of her radio  reverie.  She goes to the counter to order some coffee.   There's a commercial on the radio.  The counter WAITRESS  LORETTA is talking to the customers -- who include a  TRUCK DRIVER at a booth.  HARRIET, a short-order-cook,  is visible through an open window to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet he's tall, with a cute  butt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet he hasn't shaved in a  week.  I'll bet he stinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Harriet. (to Annie) What'll it be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee, please.  Black.  To go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should hustle myself  out to Seattle.  Give him a  little present for New Year's  Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can go there if you want  but don't open his refrigerator.   They don't cover anything when  they put it in the fridge.   They just stick it in and leave  it there till it walks out by  itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet, ever since you  divorced your last husband,  you've been no fun.  I'm  looking, and this guy pops my  tarts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Loretta, you're going  to have to jump-start this guy.   His battery's dead.  And look  at me.  Mister Ever-Ready.   Every six minutes, another  charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for someone  sensitive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, nobody wants a guy  who's sensitive on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take a call before we get  back to Sleepless.  Knoxville,  Tennessee, you're on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I would just like to know  where I could get this man's  address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the radio) Honey, get on line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Annie gets into her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie driving toward the house where Walter's parents  live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think there's somebody  out there you could love as  much as your wife? Maybe even  more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And cut back and forth between the car and the  houseboat.  Sam and Jonah are still on the bench, but  Jonah has fallen asleep in Sam's lap.  Sam is stroking  the boy's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do, Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  When I met my  wife, it was so clear.  I just  knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie is listening now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it that made you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I could really  describe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I could describe it,  it probably wouldn't be on a radio  show. (he laughs to himself) But what the hell.  It's not  one specific thing.  It's more  of a feeling. (continued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie coasts to a stop outside a handsome mansion in  Washington, D.C., the motor running.  She's hooked now,  she's not getting out of the car until she's heard it  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You touch her for the first  time, and suddenly... you're  home.  It's almost like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: realizing she has just said this.  Realizing that it  must mean something but not knowing what. SHE'S CRYING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's time to wrap up,  folks --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FIGURE appears at the passenger side window, which  Annie doesn't notice.  She's wiping the tears away with  her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hope you'll call again soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure TAPS on the window --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muffled, outside car) Annie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and let us know how it's  going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and taps again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns.  He's pointing at the locked door.  She  searches for the button.  Finally finds it so that  Walter can open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Walter.  I just  heard the most amazing thing on  the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start toward the front door, Walter and Annie  carrying presents, an overnight bag of Annie's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People call up these shows and  you can't believe the stuff  they say.  It's the end of  privacy as we know it, this  country is just one big global  village with everyone out there  going blah blah blah --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they enter the house, we hear Silent Night and we see  a Christmas tree, glittering with lights.

dialogues.speaker: A CHRISTMAS TREE GLITTERING WITH LIGHTS
dialogues.text: as we pull back to reveal:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jonah opens his presents under the tree and we cut  from gift to gift: A BROOKS ROBINSON BASEBALL GLOVE which Jonah loves and  which he puts on his hand and keeps on while continuing  to open: A TIE which mystifies him, but he hangs it around his  neck.

dialogues.speaker: A PLAID SHIRT
dialogues.text: A MAP OF THE UNITED STATES -- the kind that's used in  schoolrooms that pulls down from a roller. And now Sam brings out a long narrow present from behind  the door and Jonah opens --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jonah poses with all his Christmas presents -- his  tie hanging around his neck over his bathrobe and new  plaid shirt, his baseball glove, fishing rod -- as Sam  takes his picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam opens his present from Jonah, which is something he  made in woodworking class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hopes are perfect --  beautiful, identical, smooth --  and they are for something  really amazing I feel it in my  bones --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a spice rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We desperately need a spice  rack.  Desperately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we desperately need spices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Sam is putting the spices they have -- pepper,  salt, paprika and oregano -- into the spice rack, which  has room for at least twenty more.  Jonah is  methodically making pancakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad?  About last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's never happening again.   Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it never happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam goes to answer the door. TWO YOUNG WOMEN are standing there.  Both are wearing  quite a lot of Spandex.  One of them is named LULU.  It  says so on her jacket.  The other is JOBETH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.  Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking in and seeing  Jonah) You must be Jonah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to her friend) See.  I told you.  Sam and  Jonah.  I'm LULU.  This is  JoBeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JoBeth nods, and continues to nod as Lulu talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues) We live two piers over, don't  we? Number 12, right? We're  having like a really neat open  house today from like four to  whenever if you care to stop  by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, but... we've got plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here's the number.  If  you ever find yourself  Sleepless, give us a call.  We  also... do babysitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She winks.  JoBeth nods. Sam nods. Lulu waves goodbye, and she and JoBeth sashay off down  the dock. Jonah closes the door and turns to Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My feelings exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah and Sam are fishing off a dingy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many people do you think  heard that thing last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It plays in 50 states.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody else is going to know it  was us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. (after a beat) You better hope so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large open newsroom-type space with REPORTERS at  computers.  Around the perimeter are glass-partitioned  offices and meeting rooms.  Inside one of the offices is  BECKY, the Lifestyle editor of the Sun.  She's at a  table with Annie, now a reporter for the section, and  two other colleagues -- KEITH and WYATT.  Wyatt is  playing Gameboy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man sells the greatest  soup you've ever eaten, there's  a line around the block, and he  is, I am not kidding, the meanest  man in America. (beat) I feel strongly about this,  Becky.  This is not just about  soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it.  What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New Year's Eve.  Please don't  make me write it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becky looks at Wyatt, notices the Gameboy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyatt, I do not mean to remind  you of your mother, but if you  don't put that game away, no TV  for a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing it to the  center of the table) Would someone look this up,  don't tell me where.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becky is riffling through some papers on the table,  among which are some tearsheets from the Associated  Press wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to this.  Phone service  in the greater Chicago area was  tied up for two hours Christmas  Eve because some kid called a  phone-in show to get a wife for  his father.  Two thousand women  called in for the number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard it.  This kid calls up  and says my dad needs a wife  and I'm talking to myself in  the car saying, this is  completely disgusting, you're  taking advantage of a child,  and then the father gets on and  this shrinkette says, do you  want to talk about it? And he  says no as a matter of fact I  don't, and I am saying, bravo!  Right on! Don't talk to her,  it's none of her business -- (she's completely into  this story now) -- and then suddenly, for no  reason at all, he's talking  about how much he loved his  wife, and how he just -- (she snaps her fingers) fell in love with her and I am  crying.  Me.  A tear is  actually rolling down my face.   It was like what happens when I  watch those phone company ads.   I don't have to see the whole  ad, I just have to see the part  where the daughter gives her  mother a refrigerator with a  big red bow on it, have you  seen that one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks at her.  Apparently she's finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should write something  about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waving the AP story) What it is is, there are a lot  of desperate women out there  looking for love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially over a certain age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie is looking at them.  This isn't what she was  talking about at all, although she isn't quite sure what  she was talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is easier to be killed by a  terrorist after the age of 40  than it is to get married --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not true.  That  statistic is not true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not true, but it feels  true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's practically a whole  book about how that statistic  is not true --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down.  You brought it up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) I did not, Wyatt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, everyone pauses.  Things are a little out of  hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where were we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New Year's Eve.  I'll do it,  okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If someone is a widower, why do  they say he was widowed? Why  don't they say he was widowered?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks at her strangely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was jus wondering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie walking purposefully, followed by Becky, hurrying  to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that about up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becky and Annie are having lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Sleepless in Seattle"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what she called him on  the show.  Because he can't  sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now 2,000 women want his  number.  The guy could be a  crackhead, a psychopath, a  flasher, a junkie, a  transvestite, a chain-saw  murderer, or someone really  sick, like Rick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, he sounded nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? Oh, really? Now we're  getting down to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches down for her purse.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. REMODEL HOUSE
dialogues.text: A hand reaching down to pick something up -- the Seattle  newspaper, and

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: Sam carrying the paper down/up the stairs to an old  house that's being renovated.  Jonah, who is playing  Cameboy, is walking along with him.  WORKMEN are active  everywhere.  Dry wall going up, cabinets being  installed, tile being set. One of Sam's partners, BOB LANGMAN, is walking with him,  and JAY MATHEWS, the on-site supervisor, is waiting for  them in an unfinished doorframe.  Bob is hefty, older,  always eating something dietetic.  Jay is younger and  always wears as little as possible, even in cold weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now she wants a circular  stairwell off the den.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jonah, in b.g.) Punch me, punch in right here. (points to his stomach; Jonah punches) And she wants the Sub-Zero with  the side-by-side doors --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which means --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cabinets have to be redone  --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all nod at each other.  The woman has been a  nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we thought --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since you're on the make again  --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam looks at Jonah --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.  This is great.  The  whole town knows.  Just out of  curiosity, how do you two know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace heard it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace the dispatcher.  Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is, take the client  out to dinner and ask her to  marry you and then maybe we  won't have to redo the kitchen  cabinets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me? What about Jay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, my plate is full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, okay.  What's the big  deal?  If she'll forget the  new fireplace, I'll marry her.   Just point me in the right  direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, I don't know about this  one --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're changing your mind  --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with this  one? Wouldn't you like to have  Imelda Marcos as your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam cuffs him good-naturedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We better take the measurements  for the new cabinets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks away past some workmen, ladders, etc.  and  starts checking the cross-beams in the ceiling over in  another area of the site.  Bob follows after him.  Jay  tosses Jonah a hammer and they start knocking nails into  the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, if you're not doing  anything New Year's --  obviously you're not doing  anything New Year's -- we're  having some people over, all of  them married, not one even  remotely interested in playing  around.  Does that sound great  or what? (whistfully) I can't think of the last time  I was at a party when anything  actually happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, but I'll pass.  It's  kind of a big night.  I don't  like to leave Jonah alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah watching it.  Sam visible in the distance in the  kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sam is busy installing the spice rack.  He marks the  wall, hammers in the nails, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he starts putting  new spices into the  rack, in alphabetical  order) Does red pepper go under R or  P?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P. (beat) Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (absently) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot to mention.  Jed  called --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just out of curiosity, do you  have any friends whose names  don't begin with a J?  I feel  like it was a failure of the  imagination on our part naming  you Jonah. (looking at the spices) What is marjoram? Does anyone  know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jed is having a slumber party  New Year's Eve and he invited  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.  Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I can go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. (almost done with the  spices) Looking good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't you have used a  toggle bolt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I know how to have a  spice rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts in the last spice. They stand back to admire it.  A beat.  The rack falls  off the wall. The rack itself doesn't break, but about six of the  glass jars of spices break. There's paprika and thyme and currying powder, etc.  all  over the floor along with shards of glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God fucking dammit!  Shit!  Fuck.  Piss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah bursts into tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still angry) I'm sorry. (softening) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up Jonah and holds him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  I'm just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  I'm sorry, Jonah, I'm  sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he holds Jonah as Jonah calms down.  Sam closes his  eyes tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And pull back to reveal:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam, alone, watching the ball drop.  He's got a bag of  Doritos and a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have half your beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Maggie. She takes his bottle of beer and pours half of it into a  glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I used to say? Here's  looking at you? Here's mud in  your eye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to us.  You used to say  here's to us. (he looks at her and  his eyes well with  tears) Oh babe.  I miss you so much it  hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches out for her.  She's gone. And we hear the television set now counting down to  midnight in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same television show counting down to midnight. Champagne corks popping, etc. And we see Walter and Annie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy New Year, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy New Year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start to dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking, I have to go up  to Boston for the AAP  convention and then visit  Winston-Hughes about switching  over our computers.  Why don't  we meet in New York for  Valentine's Day weekend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, I'd love to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll stay at the Plaza --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go for a walk in Central Park --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to the Symphony --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will? (beat) The Symphony? (beat) Okay. (beat) I'll take you to the Russian  Tea Room for pelmeni.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's delicious, trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it have wheat in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go on dancing.  It's one of those parties where  everyone looks so happy and so in love.  Annie, however,  looks thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: ET. MARINA PARKING AREA
dialogues.text: Sam gets out of his car and starts down the dock toward  his houseboat.  He's carrying a bag of groceries. In the parking lot is a U.S.  MAIL TRUCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam approaches his boat and a puzzled look comes over  his face. A MAILMAN with a sack of mail is standing outside the  front door of the houseboat.  Jonah is signing a receipt  for the mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this, Dad.  They're  all for you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam picks up an envelop and looks at it.  It's  addressed to Sleepless in Seattle c/o Dr.  Marcia  Fieldstone, Radio Station KWRS in Chicago.  He's  stunned.  As he signs the receipt:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're having trouble  sleeping, you might want to try  drinking a glass of water from  the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought that was for hiccups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it work for hiccups?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For hiccups, a spoonful of  sugar, you hold it in your  mouth for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mailman starts back toward the mail truck. Sam and Jonah start toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is in the kitchen making dinner.  Jonah is sitting  at the table, reading the letters from the stack they  found by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just out of curiosity, how did  they get our address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They called and asked for it. (reading) "Dear Sleepless in Seattle.   You are the most attractive man  I've ever laid ears on."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah rolls his eyes, tosses the letter into a pile of  rejects, opens another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did they get our phone  number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to give them your  phone number or they won't let  you go on the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam nods as if this makes perfect sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues, reading) "Dear Sleepless in Seattle: I  am an SWF"-- (to Sam) What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God.  Something you don't  know.  It's a single white  female.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is no good.  She's looking  for someone French.  Or Greek. (puzzled, he throws the  letter into the reject  pile, opens another) "Dear Sleepless in Seattle: I  live in Tulsa." Where is that?  --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oklahoma.  Do you know where  that is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to think about  what they're not teaching you  in school.  I am not going to  think about it. (beat) Generally speaking I think we  should rule out people who  don't live somewhere near here  --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's willing to fly anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jonah hands Sam the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks like my third grade  teacher.  I hated my third  grade teacher.  Hold it! Wait  a minute! She is my third  grade teacher!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, you're not taking this  seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not how you do it. (referring to the  hamburger) You want this on an English  muffin or a bun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: English muffin.  How do you do  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see someone you like, you  get a feeling about them, you  ask them if they want to have a  drink or --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a slice of pizza --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not dinner necessarily on  the first date because by the  time you're halfway through  dinner you might be sorry you  asked them to dinner whereas if  it's just a drink, if you like  them you can always ask them  for dinner but if you don't you  can go home if you see what I  mean. (beat) I wonder if it still works this  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't.  They ask you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm starting to notice that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie and Walter are making love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you get a new wife, I guess  you'll have sex with her, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will she scratch up your back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JONAH'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: As Sam puts Jonah to sleep.  Jonah is holding his teddy  bear while this conversation concludes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the movies women are always  scratching up guy's back and  screaming and stuff.  When  they're having sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose show was this on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jed's got cables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses him good-night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiss Howard. (he holds out the  teddy bear) G'night, Howard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie and Walter have just finished making love. Walter falling asleep. Annie lying in bed, with her eyes open. She starts to get out of bed.  Puts on a robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Annie comes downstairs in a bathrobe. She opens the door to the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Annie starts to run down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now we widen out to see a misty highway she's running down. Past a sign saying: Seattle Approximately 3,000 miles. Past another sign: Your nerves are shot. And another: Your feet are cold. And another: Will you find love. And another: Before you're cold? And another: Burma Shave. And Annie continues to run, and now we see she's running  across a map of the United States -- it's a little like  the one we saw in the beginning of the movie -- it's  like the famous map of the United States by Saul  Steinberg, but instead of being about New York, this one  is about Seattle. In the distance, at the very edge of the map, we see two  indistinct figures -- a map and a young boy.  They start  to wave at her, very slowly. Annie's eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie in bed, eyes open.  Walter fast asleep. She gets out of bed, puts on her robe (just as she did  in the dream sequence).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Annie comes down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns the light on. Opens the refrigerator. Closes it. Opens it again.  Takes out some milk. Sits down at the kitchen table with a bowl, corn flakes,  banana.  She's about to assemble it when: She sees:

dialogues.speaker: THE RADIO
dialogues.text: She stands up, turns it on to the station Dr. Marcia  Fieldstone is on.  She sits back down with her corn  flakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up next, "You and Your  Emotions" with Dr.  Marcia  Fieldstone, clinical  psychologist and the best  friend you never had. (the teaser continues)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he doesn't love me any  more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you want to be with  someone who doesn't love you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time I come close to  orgasm he stops and goes to  make himself a sandwich --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you make him a  sandwich beforehand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I met my wife, it was so  clear.  I jus knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie starts at hearing Sam's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it that made you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I could really  describe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I could describe it, it  probably wouldn't be on a radio  show. (he laughs to himself) But what the hell.  It's not  one specific thing.  It's more  of a feeling.   (continuing) You touch her for the first  time, and suddenly... you're  home.  It's almost like...  magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be back after this  commercial with Dr. Marcia  Fieldstone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Annie's car pull into a parking space outside the  Peabody Library.  Annie gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Annie strides purposefully across the library and  enters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie bursts into Tom's office and walks over to his  desk.  We barely has time to look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm going crazy, Tom.   I really do.  Are you happily  married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (completely panicked by  the question) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, why did you get  married? Was it all fireworks  and trumpets and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (regaining composure) I got married because Betsy  said we had to break up or get  married.  So we get married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But when you met her, did you  believe she was the only person  for you? That in some mystical,  cosmic way, it was fated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, when you meet someone  and you're attracted to them,  it just means that your  subconscious is attracted to  their subconscious,  subconsciously.  So what we  think of as chemistry is just  two neuroses knowing that they  are a perfect match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even know him.  But  I'm having all these fantasies  about a man I've never met,  who lives in Seattle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It rains nine months of the  year in Seattle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know.  I do not want  to move to Seattle.  But what I  really don't want to do is end  up always wondering what might  have happened and knowing I  could have done something.   What do you think? (Tom opens his mouth to  say something, but  before anything comes  out, Annie fills the  void) It's just cold feet, isn't it?  Everyone panics before they get  married, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Tom.  I feel so much  better just having blown this  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Annie walks through it and pushes the door to exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Jay walk out of the Arctic Building onto the  street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandy has a girlfriend, Clenda ... She's a weightlifter, but  it's not like her neck is  bigger than her head or  anything --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not asking you to set me  up, Jay.  That's not what I  need your help for.  I want to  know what it's like over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's what I'm trying to  tell you.  What women are  looking over, okay? Pecs and a  cute butt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, like, "He has the  cutest butt"? Where did I hear  that recently?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everywhere.  You can't even  turn on the news without  hearing about how some babe  thought some guy's butt was  cute.  Who the first babe to  say this was I don't know,  but it caught on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Jay at the counter.  Out the window, we can see  water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's the latest time you were  out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to remember) Seventy... eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  Things are different.   First, you have to be friends.   You have to like each other.   Then you neck.  This can go on  for years.  Then you have  tests.  Then you get to do it  with a condom. (beat) The good news is, split the  check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it could let a  woman pay for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.  They'll have a parade  in your honor.  You'll be Man  of the Year in Seattle  Magazine.  Tira misu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's tira misu?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some woman is going to want me  to do it to her and I'm not  going to know what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) This is going to be tougher  than I thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam coming home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he enters.  It's very quiet.  Too quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to look concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes down the hall to Jonah's room.  The door is  shut.  He opens it. Jonah is sitting on his bed listening to a tape.   Earphones on.  Next to him is a young girl named  JESSICA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah takes off the earphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad.  Dad, this is Jessica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice to meet you, Jessica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, this is amazing.  If you  play this backwards, it says  "Paul is dead."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam shrugs, turns to go back down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, could you close the door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H and G. (Sam looks back) Hi and goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam closes the door to Jonah's room. Hold on Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Get a life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sam comes downstairs, goes into his office.  Closes  the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the phone.  Looks up a number in the phone  book.  Picks up the phone and dials a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Victoria?... It's Sam  Baldwin, I don't know if you  remember me.  Oh?  Well, great.   I was wondering if you wanted  to have a drink... Friday,  say... Dinner?... Sure, dinner  would be fine.  Sure.  Dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie is watching "An Affair to Remember" on television,  tears pouring down her face.  Cary Grant is saying: "Are  you in love with him?" Deborah Kerr replies: "I'm not  now." She's sitting at the dining room table.  A dozen pieces  of paper litter the table.  Annie's been unsuccessfully  typing a letter on an old Underwood typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now those were the days when  people knew how to be in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a blast from the wine glass to her right.   Becky leans in, refilling the glass.  Annie begins to  type and sob and look at the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a basket case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she types) They knew it.  Time, distance,  nothing could separate them.   Because they knew.  It was  right.  It was real.  It was...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... movie. (beat) That's your problem.  You don't  want to be in love.  You want  to be in love in a movie. (beat) Read it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading her letter) "Dear Sleepless and Son..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds like the name of a  mattress store --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I am not the sort of person  who listens to call-in radio  shows" --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becky flops on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this woman is a writer!  That's what everyone writes at  the beginning of letters to  strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that.  You think I don't  know that? "I know that's a  dumb way to begin, but it's the  only way I can think of to  convey what happened to me the  other night when I heard the  two of you on the radio.  On  the other hand, maybe I'm just  losing my mind."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are.  You're losing your  mind.  What about Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to marry Walter.  I  just have to get this out of my  system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should say something in this  about magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I mean, what if  I never meet him? What if this  man is my destiny and I never  meet him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your destiny can be your doom.   Look at me and Rick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (typing some more) "I want to meet you..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cary Grant says: "How about the top of the Empire State  Building?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "On top of the Empire State  Building at sunset on  Valentine's Day."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Perfect.  I'll be in New  York with Walter, I can squeeze  it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She types in Becky's idea. Then she takes the piece of paper out of the typewriter,  smashes it into a ball and tosses it up in the air and  into Becky's lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to hear about destiny?  If my husband hadn't gone on a  diet, which caused me to leave  him, I would never have been on  that flight to Miami, and met  Rick, and ended up having sex  in the bathroom of a 727 with  that nob you slide that says  "vacant-occupied, vacant- occupied, vacant-occupied" -- (she shudders in  ecstasy, then pulls  herself together)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never told me you left your  husband because he went on a  diet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods; after a beat) He lost all the weight...  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's impossible.  A guy can't  --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then you left him? He lost  weight there and you left him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plus he fell in love with a  temp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to this, I love this  part --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deborah Kerr says: "It's now or never." And Cary Grant  says: "We'd be fools to let happiness pass us by."  Deborah Kerr: "Winter must be cold for those with no  warm memories." Becky and Annie with tears rolling down their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men never get this movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think at the end of the  movie when she's in the  wheelchair they can still do  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always wondered about that  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Becky reaches for a Kleenex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Kleenex being pulled from a box.  Sam is giving it to  Jonah, who's up.  His hair is mated with perspiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, it's okay.  I'm  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat while Jonah calms down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was sinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our house.  There was water  coming in all the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calm and definite) You're worried we're going to  be all right.  We're going to  be all right. (Sam gives Jonah a  squeeze) I remember sometimes you'd have  nightmares as a baby.  Your mom  would hold you and rock you and  sing you a song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye bye blackbird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what she used to sing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss her. (beat) What do you think happens to  someone after they die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like do you believe in heaven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never did.  Or the whole idea  of an afterlife.  But I don't  know any more.  I have these  dreams about... your mom... and  we have long talks about...  about you, and how you are,  which she sort of knows but I  tell her anyway.  So what is  that? It's sort of an afterlife,  isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm starting to forget her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  But she's here, Jonah.   Because I have you.  And as  long as I have you, I have your  Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on the two of them as music begins.  Bye Bye  Blackbird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... uh... have a date with  someone Friday night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I ever tell you about the  time I ate a dog biscuit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jonah cuddles closer MUSIC COMES UP AS WE PULL BACK  FROM THE BED AND...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
